newsitem.title: USA: Bones may be of Florida teens missing 18 years.
newsitem.headline: Bones may be of Florida teens missing 18 years.

text.p: Human bones in a mud-filled van found at the bottom of a canal are probably the remains of five teenagers who vanished nearly 18 years ago, authorities said on Sunday.
The rusted van, covered with algae, was discovered by chance a week ago when a tow truck was pulling another vehicle from the 20-foot- (six-metre-) deep canal.
Beer bottles found in the van and other evidence suggested the youths were victims of a traffic accident, authorities said. Foul play was not suspected.
The five skeletons were not positively identified, Palm Beach County Sheriff's spokesman Paul Miller said.
"Identification is going to take a very long time," he said. "We have the names of the five individuals who we believe were in the van and whose remains we believe we have."
The discovery ended nearly two decades of uncertainty for the families of the five, four boys and a girl, who vanished July 14, 1979.
"In my heart I knew he couldn't have been alive and not have contacted me," Peggy Kelly, mother of the owner of the van, 18-year-old Matthew Henrich, told the Miami Herald.
The last time she saw her son he was headed to the beach to meet some friends.
When the van was pulled from the canal, it was filled with muck and no bodies were visible. It was taken to a salvage yard where it was destined for the scrap heap.
When workers opened the van's doors, they spotted a bone. Police found more bones in the van along with Matthew Henrich's wallet, with cash and identification in it.
